content.description:
P1: great hand crack in a right facing corner. 5.9 45m P2: garbage climb up broken flakes and heather gully. 5.8 35m P3: We climbed up a short chimney (with hand cracks inside for hands and protection), but went left up a small slab and into a tough stem box. I think the actual climb goes slight right after the chimney, also into a stembox, but probably much easier than what we did. It was supposed to be a 5.10a pitch, 25m P4: Thin and fun finger crack. 5.10d 35m P5: Money pitch. Starts off tight hands, becomes great hands, then you can go left for more hands (I believe) or you can go right for a zig-zag finger lock... PUMPY! Supposed to be 5.10b (maybe the left way?) 45m P6: Unless you have a #6 with you, an unprotected 5.7 off-width. Not tall... Summit! West face of South Spire Full set of nuts
Doubles from tips (0.2 BD size) to 0.75, then maybe triples of 1s and 2s.
Then singles of 3 and 4
Some people suggest RPs. I don't think I used any, but I did use small nuts.
All anchors are gear anchors

climbs.name: Ensawkwatch Enchainment (D)
climbs.fa: Kobus Barnard, John Black, Emily Butler (1993)

content.description:
From Kevin McLane's Alpine Select: This is a traverse of the two Nesakwatch Spires and Rexford, linking the two north ridges of the Spires, by descent on their south sides, into the narrow col between S. Spire and Rexfor. Climb a few pitches up the short NW face of Rexford to the summit and descend via the W. ridge route.

single rack, long draws, 30m rope.

History An excellent short route that was first Soloed on a dry day in December! Route Description P1 - Start at the base of a large chimney and stem your way to the top of the landing! Having your follower carry the backpack through this section would be cruel and unusual punishment... P2 - Climb a short section of excellent hand/fist jams (save your red and blues!) to the top of a short slab, then finish it off with a finger/hand sized crack, belay at the landing above. P3 - Make your way to the top of the shelf and made a dynamic move to the jug above on thin feet, short climbers may find this section difficult. P4 - Scramble between the flakes to the top of the col between North and South Spire. (Not pictured) Descent Follow the ridge line down and take the standard descent trail down to the basin, at time of writing it is flagged with pink flagging tape from SAR and starts just below a large boulder marked in the photos.  From the camp basin walk towards the South spire, the route is left  of "Frog Face" as listed in the Fraser Valley Guidebook Eds.1 linked (free or by donation) below:

https://fvclimbingsociety.com/download/fvcs-guidebook/

Go up the ramp and traverse left *carefully* into the base of a wide chimney, this is a tight squeeze and a party of 3 may opt to start lower down and scramble into the chimney to start.  Standard double rack of C4's (0.3-3) and a single #4 should suffice. Triples of 1,2 and 3's may be warranted for those who want more protection on p2 as the gear anchor chews up your larger pro.

Gear Anchors on all belays.

climbs.name: North Nesakwatch Spire - Nesakwatch Notch (NE Buttress)

content.description:
A big route from the 80s that is still probably unrepeated. Finding the route in condition can be problematic as it depends on snow through the notch but is then a rock climb. Access from Centre Creek. Cross the creek and climb a snow gully into the basin as per Rexford north face. Head right towards North Nesakwatch Spires NE rib/buttress, aiming for the huge cleft. Climb snow into this cleft and under the free-standing chockstone. Downclimb a pitch on the other side of the notch, below the N face. Climb steep and inobvious rock and bush (mostly 5.7 but with moves to 5.9+) for 5 pitches, right of the notch, to gain the crest of the buttress above the notch. Follow this to the summit (7-8 pitches to 5.6)

See TOPO
Gear to 3" plus crampons, ice tools and some snow/ice protection. Possibly a few pins.

climbs.name: North Nesakwatch Spire - NW Face Right(Neufeld/Struthers)

content.description:
The route climbs a long straight crack system on the left (north) flank of the west ridge. It features climbing from fingers to fist crack width.

see TOPO
Gear to 4" with multiple 3" pieces

climbs.name: North Nesakwatch Spire - NW Face to W Ridge
climbs.fa: FRA Drew Brayshaw, Shaun Neufeld May 2014

content.description:
From the base of the northwest face, climb a diagonal ramp (4th class rock and snow) to gain the upper west ridge below the 5.7 crack pitch. Continue to the summit on the upper west ridge. Good early season route.

See topo photo
A few cams and nuts to 2". Crampons and ice axe in early season

climbs.name: North Spire - North Ridge (PD+)
climbs.fa: Bruce Fairley, Keith Cover, Anders Ourom, Roy Schneider (July 1984)

content.description:
From Kevin McLane's Alpine Select:  
  
 An excellent moderate climb, with plenty of 3rd and 4th class. Exposed and airy. Difficulties are avoided on either side. Descent via south ridge scramble.

Single rack and long draws.

climbs.name: North Spire - SW Ridge
climbs.fa: John Howe and Mike Down in the early 80s

content.description:
Approach: From the basin walk over to the low 5th class chimneys either rope up there or scramble up to the base of P1.

P1 5.8ish: The obvious cracks containing a few fixed pieces including a fun rigid stem friend. Belay at the horizontal on the ledge.

P2 5.8: Traverse right along the ledge and up the short splitter finger crack, belay to the left before the left facing corner. Pitches 1 and 2 can probably be linked.

P3 5.8+: Drop down and climb the steep cracks until you can step right into the corner. Follow that up to a slab to either a wide 4”? flake, or a wide crack to its left. Belay either off the boulder horn or build an anchor in the corner.

P4 5.7ish: Scramble up to the splitter cracks, follow those and some slabby terrain up to the flat section of the ridge.

P5 4th ~100m: Simul or unrope and scramble to the base of the headwall cracks.

P6 5.8ish: Climb the perfect cracks up to more blocky terrain above, either build an anchor there or lower/down climb to the flat area below.

P7: low 5th loose blocks: carefully climb up the Jenga blocks to the summit.

Descent: The descent follows easy terrain down the standard S-ridge of the spire. In earlier season that route may be hazardous due to snow. There is a neglected rap route that weaves it's way down the south face which might be a better option conditions depending.

Rack: x2 BD.4-2, x1 3-4, Nuts, long slings.

climbs.name: South Spire - East Buttress
climbs.fa: Drew Brayshaw, Marc-Andre Leclerc, Jesse Mason, 2009; FWA Marc-Andre Leclerc (solo) 2017

content.description:
This route climbs immediately right (north) of the Priest-Coupe couloir that divides Rexford from South Nesakwatch Spire. It is a fun 9-pitch rock climb, but requires a long snow slog to reach and is best done early in the season before the snow melts. Crampons and ice axes are required for the approach. Most of the climbing is 5.7, but there are a couple of short 5.9 sections that can be avoided. A very full day out, especially if descending west into Nesakwatch Creek and then returning to a vehicle parked in Centre Creek

Cross Centre Creek and approach up the snow gully as for the North Face of Rexford or the Priest-Coupe couloir. At the bergschrund at the base of the P-C, move right onto rock and climb 9 pitches of slabs, cracks and ledges.
A light rack from nuts to 3" cams is sufficient. Bring a 4" or 5" cam or big balls if climbing the offwidth summit block on South Nesakwatch.

climbs.name: South Spire - North Ridge (AD-)
climbs.fa: Kobus Barnard, John Black, Emily Butler (1993)

content.description:
The elegant ridge gives a pleasant climb, generally to the left of the crest. The final pitch is a short squeeze chimney that is difficult to protect without large gear. Sling the flake to rap off. descent is by scrambling the south ridge.

Single rack - large gear (optional) for final pitch, 30m rope

The line of first ascent. Do not ascend the rappel route described under the Enchainment). Climb all the way to the South Spire-Rexford col, i.e. to climber's right of the rap route. Climbblocky 4th class terrain up and right, moving out around the corner of the spire onto the upper east buttress, then curving back to climber's left, for around 2 pitches in total. This brings you to the base of the South Spire summit block, which is split entirely through by an offwidth. The north side of the summit OW is easier than the south side! There's no good anchor on top, but a person on the base one side can hold the rope fixed while a climber on top raps down the opposite side of the block.

Right out of the notch.
Bring a 4" or 4.5" cam for the 15 foot summit block offwidth.

Start on the right side of the buttress near the gully. Scramble into an alcove. Climb cracks on the right wall of the alcove for a pitch, then black-lichened slabs for a pitch to the base of a pair of corners. Climb the right corner* (crux, offwidth on the right with a hand crack on the left) to a good ledge. A short 5.7 pitch leads to the summit ridge.

A direct start begins further left and climbs two 5.9 pitches to join in on the black-lichened slabs

*The left corner has also been climbed at a similar grade. 


The furthest right climb on the west face of South Nesakwatch
Full rack from finger sized wired nuts to 4" cam.

From Kevin McLane's Alpine Select:  
  
 The two elegant towers of North and South Nesakwatch Spires are prominent on the crest of the divide just north of Rexford's north summit. The climbs described are short but airy with a very alpine feel to them, and are all reached from the Nesakwatch creek. Considering the amount of good granite, this area receives surprisingly little attention. South Nesakwatch Spire is immediately north of the summit of Rexford, and although from the west side it appears to be part of Rexford, the two are separated by a deep, barrow col. North Nesakwatch Spire is the lower but more prominent of the two spires, about 300m to the north.
